original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified:
Your dreams can give you ideas about things you didn't think about before. Some dreams are common and mean the same thing for many people. For example, flying in your dreams means you feel free, falling means you feel scared or out of control, losing your teeth means you're worried about something, and being naked in public means you're embarrassed about something. 

To understand what your dreams mean to you, think about what happened in your life recently and how you felt. Connect your dreams to these things. This will help you understand your dreams better.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.
simplified:
Wild dogs live in Moscow. There are about 35,000 of them. They live on the streets and some of them are not afraid of people. Some dogs were born in the wild, while others were pets that their owners left behind. Some dogs are alone and others live in groups.

Some scientists studied the dogs in 2010. They found out that the dogs are very good at living in the city. They have learned to cross the streets safely with people and some dogs even know how to use traffic lights.

original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States and has already won several awards. Many schools are using it as a starting point for discussions about bullying, friendship and what it's like to be different. A film version is being made, and many, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.
simplified:
RJ Palacio is an American writer. She wrote a book called Wonder. RJ Palacio said she had an idea for the book when she saw a girl with a face that was different from others on the street. 

Wonder is a very popular book in the United States. It has won several awards. Many schools are using the book to talk about important things like bullying and being different. A film is being made about the book. People are excited to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.
simplified:
Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. She knows that rats are not like other pets. People often think they are dirty, but Chloe says they can be great pets if you take care of them. 

Chloe used to think rats were not nice pets. But then her friend Martin showed her his rats. She saw how friendly and smart they were. After that, Chloe wanted a pet rat too. Last year, Martin's rat had babies. Chloe got two of them.

original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.
simplified: Cape Town can be a bad place for baboons. Some baboons get hurt or killed in car accidents. Others get electrocuted when they play with electric wires. Baboons are in danger and the city council wants to help them. They want to stop baboons and humans from having problems. They have a team of Baboon Monitors. Their job is to chase baboons away from the city or catch them and take them to the countryside. This plan is working a little bit, but it's hard to keep the baboons from coming back to the city. They like the food in the city.

original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this flexibility is very valuable to me because it means that I can easily take some time off when my children need me to go to their school performances or if I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist. The downside is that without clear office hours, I tend to work well into the evening, sometimes skipping dinner to finish a task.
simplified: I work for a big company that helps people use computers. My boss is in America, so I do my job from home. I like this because I don't have to go to the office every day and talk to my colleagues. I work on different projects and this is good for me because I can take time off when my children need me to go to school. If I have a dentist appointment, I can also go then. But sometimes I work late into the evening and I don't eat dinner until I finish my work.

original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. simplified: People see many things to buy on social media, magazines, and shop windows every day. They buy more clothes and shoes than before. It is easy to buy things online without thinking. Some big brands sell cheap clothes. We can buy and use them a few times and then throw them away.

original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. The more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr, Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. The damp patches on his shirt drew together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning ruddy in the June sun. Otherwise he had the indoor tan of a man that made money while other people did the work.
simplified: Sam looked at the dust from a car on the way to the Big House. The horses were kicking and swishing their tails at flies. They didn't care that their owner, Mr Carter, was coming to visit after ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't usually come outside unless he had to. Sam liked it that way. The more he stayed out of trouble, the longer he'd have his job. Mr Carter wiped the sweat from his neck. The wet spots on his shirt were like small shapes. His skin was getting red from the sun. He looked like a man who worked indoors and made money, while other people did the hard work.

original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
simplified: Some people in Berlin are unhappy about shooting pigs. They think it is cruel. There are fights between people who hunt and people who love animals. The city council heard the complaints. They decided to do something else to stop the pigs. They put up fences and said it is not allowed to feed the pigs. We will see if this works. The winters are getting warmer, so there are more pigs now than before.

original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. In this story, the city of Athens is ruled by another city called Crete. The people of Athens are angry and they want to be free. As a punishment, the king of Crete makes the people of Athens send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. These children are thrown into a big maze and eaten by a monster called the Minotaur. But one of the children, Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne thinks Katniss Everdeen, the main character in The Hunger Games, is like Theseus in a modern story.

original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.
simplified: Zoos help people understand how to protect animals and their homes. They also help animals that have been hurt or left alone. Some zoos give a safe place to animals that were treated badly in circuses or abandoned as pets. Zoos do research to learn more about how animals behave and how to make them healthy.

original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.
simplified: There's a new movement against buying too much. This movement is called the 'buy nothing' trend. It started in Canada a long time ago and then went to the US. The people who started it wanted to stop overspending on special days like Black Friday and Cyber Monday. On these days, people usually buy a lot of things. On Buy Nothing Day, people protest and some even cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, groups help people give or fix things they already have instead of buying new ones.

original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. Many street artists have been stopped by the police and some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain about the high cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.
simplified:
Is graffiti art or vandalism? 
This depends on how you see it. But for many people, writing or painting on public or private property is vandalism. 

In many countries, the police stop street artists and some have to pay fines. City councils are unhappy about the cost of cleaning graffiti off buildings, buses and trains.

original: What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, there has been a growing recognition of its value as an art form. simplified: What do people in the art world think of graffiti and street art? They are starting to see it as a real art form. Many big exhibitions have taken place in galleries in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. An American artist named Elura Emerald had a big exhibition of street art in New York in 2008. She said that street artists are just expressing themselves, and they're not hurting anyone. They should be happy that people are showing interest in their work.

original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.
simplified: Most people have four to six dreams every night after they are ten years old. This means they have 2,000 dreams per year. When they are 80 years old, they might have had 140,000 dreams. If we forget most of our dreams, we still remember a few thousand. It's not hard to believe that a dream is followed by something similar happening in real life. This can happen especially if the dream is about something that happens often.

The Hunger Games takes place in the future, after North America was destroyed.

original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. They open rubbish bins and eat fruit from gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from kitchen cupboards and fridges! simplified: Wild animals come into cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, some baboons are coming into people's houses to eat. original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.
simplified: Many accidents happen when building a bridge. These accidents often happen because the engineers made a mistake. They might have calculated something wrong. The bridge can fall down under its own weight. This can be very bad for the workers who are on the bridge when it happens.

original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.
simplified: George Lucas was one of the first film directors to use the story of the hero's journey. The hero starts with an ordinary life, but then something happens and they go on a big adventure. In Star Wars, the main character, Luke, lives with his aunt and uncle. They fix robots. Then, Luke finds a message from a princess in a robot called R2D2. This is the moment that makes him go on a big adventure.

original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.
simplified:
A possible way to stop an asteroid from hitting Earth is to blow it up with a nuclear bomb. This is like a scene from a movie, but NASA really thought of this idea. It's called HAMMER, a plan to stop an asteroid from hitting us. 

First, they would fire big rockets at the asteroid to push it away from its path. If the asteroid is very close to Earth, the rockets would have a special bomb that would blow the asteroid up instead.

original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.
simplified:
According to Campbell, the hero at first says no to the adventure. But then a helper appears and they decide to go into a special place where the adventure happens. 

In Luke's story, his helper is Obi-Wan. He meets friends like Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO. But he also meets his enemy, Darth Vader, in a bad place called the Death Star.

original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.
simplified: We can use old things and they may seem useless, but they can be useful for someone else. With the internet, people have found a way to make money by sharing these old things with others. They use websites and social media groups to find people who want to buy or sell second-hand things. It is now easier for people to share things with each other, and this is known as the sharing economy.

original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.
simplified: There were two popular ideas about dreams in the 18th and 19th centuries. One idea was that things we see in our dreams show us things we don't know about ourselves. Freud thought that if we understand our dreams, we can know our hidden feelings and problems. But another idea was different. It said that dreams are just random things in our brain when it's working with memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and turn them into a story.

original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.
simplified: I work for myself. I like it because I'm in charge of my work and my time. At first, I worked from home. But it was difficult to concentrate. There were too many things distracting me: cleaning the house, making tea, family members wanting my attention. So, I started working in a café near my home. But the internet was not good, and I drank too much coffee. In the end, I found a place where I can rent a desk with five other people who work for themselves. I like getting dressed in the morning and working in a quiet office.

original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.
simplified:
NASA needs money to build a new telescope called NEOCam. It is a 0.5-metre space telescope that uses infrared light. If NASA gets the money, it will be able to find the middle-sized asteroids in ten years. 

When they find the middle-sized asteroids, the team will still have to work out how to protect the Earth from the big asteroids called PHAs.

original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. simplified:
The 'buy nothing' trend is now on social media. Influencers usually share things to buy, but now they're telling people not to buy anything. Some YouTube stars say don't buy anything for a year. Two friends in Canada tried this. 

They first didn't buy things like electronics, clothes, or house things for three months. Then they stopped using services like haircuts or eating out. They saved money for a year and had $55,000.

original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.
simplified: Pi likes his family's Hindu religion, but he also wants to know about other religions. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Pi says he believes in all three religions - Hindu, Muslim and Christian. His family and teachers are surprised. They ask him to choose just one, but Pi says, 'I just want to love God'. After that, his family and teachers let him decide what he wants to believe.

original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!
simplified:
Some people think writing down their dreams can help them have lucid dreams. Lucid dreams are when you know you're dreaming and you can control what happens in the dream. 

Imagine being able to change a scary nightmare into a happy dream. Or, you can be like a film director and decide what happens in your dream. Instead of just trying to understand your dreams, you can make them. But, it's also nice to have some dreams that let your subconscious mind tell you things.

original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.
simplified:
People think they're helping by donating their old clothes to charity shops. But the truth is, charity shops can't sell all the clothes they get. 

'Fast fashion' is a big problem. These cheap clothes go out of style quickly and are often of poor quality. People don't want to buy old clothes, so they end up in the bin. A lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent to other countries, causing more problems.

original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.
simplified:
Meagan McGrath from Canada is an adventurous woman. She has done many amazing things.
She climbed the highest mountain on each continent. She rode a bike across Canada. She also ran a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in very hot weather.
But her most amazing trip was to the South Pole by skiing. On the first day, she fell into a big piece of ice and had to be helped out. Many people would have stopped there, but Meagan kept going. It took her 40 days to reach the South Pole. She pulled a sledge with a tent and food behind her through very cold weather and ice storms.

original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

simplified: Some cities allow artists to paint graffiti in special areas. In Taiwan, they have 'graffiti zones' where artists can paint freely. Some artists in São Paulo, Brazil, are even allowed to paint on the city's subway trains.

original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. simplified: I think it's interesting to think about how we can make our bodies better with technology. For example, imagine if we could put a small computer in our brain. In the future, this might be possible and we could use it to make our brains work better. We could do math faster, see and hear better, and remember things more easily. This idea will probably become more popular as time goes on.

original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.
simplified: There was a very interesting talk. The speaker was right about a few things. For example, what do you think happens when teenagers see their parents using their phones a lot? They might think it's okay to use their phones too, like when they're doing their homework. The speaker said that people want to be in many places at the same time, so they look at their phones while they're talking to their friends in person. I see this a lot with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet, but then they all sit there in silence, each one looking at their phone and talking to someone else online.

original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
simplified:
The world is a violent place, but there is some good news. Between World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today, countries are mostly getting along better than before. But there is a problem - terrorism is getting worse. 

In the past, more soldiers than civilians were killed in wars. But now, many more civilians are being killed. However, the statistics for civilians are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate went down. It fell from 8 people per 100,000 in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.
simplified: Wasfia works to help people in her country, Bangladesh. She helps women and girls with human rights. But some projects stop and leave them with nothing. Wasfia thought Bangladesh should be more independent. So, she combined two things she loves: climbing mountains and helping people. She started climbing while working on other projects in Tibet and Nepal. Bangladesh is a flat country, and people don't usually see mountains there. Wasfia's campaign is working. More people in Bangladesh and around the world are paying attention to her work.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.
simplified: Most people think that countries with little money are in a bad situation. They think these countries have a lot of poverty, bad leaders and no hope for change. But this is not true. Something big is happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have become richer and are no longer poor. Every year, 6 million fewer children die from illness. More girls are going to school and many people have access to clean water.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified:
Many managers give positive and negative feedback to their employees. They put the negative feedback in the middle of two positive comments. This is called a "sandwich". But sometimes, when managers do this too much, employees think that the positive comments are just nice words and not really true. This can make the positive feedback less valuable.

Positive feedback should be given to encourage good work. It should not just be used to make the negative feedback sound nicer.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
simplified:
I am a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. 

Imagine robots that can kill people on their own. This is not just a movie idea, it's happening now. Military machines like drones and robots are being used to kill, but with some human help.

The next step could be'murderbots'. These robots would follow orders, but also make their own decisions about who to kill. This would be very bad for humanity.

We need to think carefully about what we ask machines to do. We must be very cautious.

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. simplified:
Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk to you about your recent project. You're worried all weekend, thinking you did something wrong. On Monday morning, you go to her office. She starts by saying how good you did on the project. You wonder if this is just to make her message nicer.

You know this is called the feedback sandwich. It's when you say something nice, then say what you really want to say, and then say something nice again.

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
simplified:
The music album Born in the USA has happy, upbeat songs but they also talk about sad things. Behind the fun music are stories of people's problems. Many songs are about working people who are not happy with their lives. They don't have much money or fame. 

One song, Glory Days, is about people in a small town who remember when they were young and had big dreams. Another song, Downbound Train, is about a young man who loses his job and his life gets worse. 

We can imagine that the singer, who is called the Boss, wrote these songs about people he knew and maybe even about his own life if he hadn't become famous. This album shows that the Boss is a very talented singer.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
simplified:
Lewis wants the world to have more places to protect the sea. He wants these places to go from 3% to 10% of the sea. This is because people are hurting the sea by overfishing, polluting, and throwing trash in the water. Lewis has seen this damage during his travels. He has swum over coral reefs that are white because the water is too hot. He has also seen empty underwater areas with a lot of plastic in the Red Sea.

Lewis thinks that nature can fix itself if we give it time and space. But the problem is that time is running out. If we don't take care of the sea, we might have a big problem that we can't solve.

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. simplified: Terrie Sharp is a famous writer. She has won two awards for writing crime stories. She was born on a big housing estate in Glasgow. This area had a lot of crime. To stay safe, she learned to keep quiet and not get involved in trouble. She also learned how to open car doors with a knife. She only used this skill to write her books. Now, she talks on TV shows and at writing meetings in the UK.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
simplified:
Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible? 
Steven Pinker thinks that things are actually getting better. In his book, he looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news.
We are living longer, healthier lives. We are freer and happier too. 
But, according to Pinker, there is a problem. The values of the Enlightenment, like using reason and science, are under attack. 
Some people are trying to get people to be more tribal, and to believe that the future is always bad. They also want people to distrust important institutions like democracy and working together as a world.

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
simplified:
In old horror films, people were in trouble and couldn't call the police. Now it's hard to believe that. Why? Because we all have mobile phones now. 

What's the solution to keep horror films believable? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's very likely that at a key moment, when you really need help, you won't be able to make a call. Or your phone battery will die just as you're calling.

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
simplified:
In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their most important banana, called Gros Michel or Big Mike, was dying out. Now, the same thing is happening to Big Mike's replacement, the Cavendish banana.

The Gros Michel banana was very popular because it was easy to transport, had thick skin and tasted sweet. It grew on most of the banana plantations in Central America. United Fruit, the main company growing and exporting bananas in the area, grew its bananas very efficiently. They took shoots from the stems of the plants instead of seeds, and grew them very close together in the fields.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified:
Most spiders have venom to catch their food. The venom helps to make the prey weak or dead. But spider venom is not usually meant to harm people. Only 25 out of all known spider species have venom that can hurt humans. Spider bites can be painful, but they are rarely deadly.

In Australia, there is a spider called the Sydney funnel-web. Before 1981, it was a big problem because it could kill people. But now that there is a medicine to cure its bite, no one has died from it since 1981.

Some spiders, like tarantulas, have hair on their bodies. If they feel threatened, they can release these hairs into the air. The hairs can get into the skin or eyes of people who are attacking them, and it can be very uncomfortable.

original: This horror film cliché was especially popular with horror films of the late 20th century. It starts with a group of teenagers all enjoying themselves, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At the beginning the girl is usually innocent, shy and not particularly strong. By the end, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins in the end.
simplified:
This kind of horror movie was very popular a long time ago. It usually starts with a group of young people who are happy and enjoying themselves. But in the end, everyone dies except one girl. 

The girl is often shy and not strong at the beginning. But by the end, she has become a tough and clever person. The last girl almost always survives and wins in the end.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified:
We want to know where our language came from. To find the answer, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. It's not just about how big our brains are, but also what they can do. 

Our brains are different from other animals in some important ways. But there are few clues from the past to help us understand this. We can't tell from old things that our ancestors left behind what kind of language they used. 

However, we can see that early humans had a different mouth, throat and tongue than we do now. This changed about 100,000 years ago. At that time, humans could make new and more complex sounds. Before that, scientists are not sure if early humans could only make simple sounds or not.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: Society, not nature, tells us that girls should do arts and humanities, and boys should do maths and physics. This is not true. We also don't see many women doing science jobs when we are young. Cartoons and stories often show men as scientists, inventors, and astronauts. People also think scientists are not good with others, and that their work is lonely. This is not true. These ideas come from the media, but they might stop girls from liking science and doing it as a job. If girls saw more women doing science, it would make them feel more confident and like they belong in those subjects.

original: The Scallion is printed weekly and distributed free in faculty buildings, with a readership of approximately 10,000 students. It is written and produced entirely by students. The survey shows that the newspaper is highly valued by university students and staff for entertainment, cultural enrichment and work experience. The cost of printing newspapers is significant. Furthermore, some students do not have easy access to the paper, since the only way to obtain a copy is to physically go to university. An additional environmental issue is that a large number of copies end up as litter on campus.
simplified:
The Scallion is a free newspaper that is printed every week. It is distributed in the university buildings and is read by about 10,000 students. The students write and make the newspaper themselves.

A survey showed that the students and staff think the newspaper is very good for entertainment, learning about culture and getting work experience. However, printing the newspaper is expensive.

Some students do not have a copy because they cannot go to the university to get one. Another problem is that many copies are thrown away and end up as litter on campus.

original: At Girox Foods, we are experiencing an annual employee turnover of about 12 per cent. Although this might not seem high at first glance, the industry standard is seven per cent. The principal objective of this report is to investigate the causes of employee engagement within the firm and, based on those, offer recommendations to improve the employees' experience of the workplace and increase employee retention.
simplified: At Girox Foods, many employees leave every year. This is 12 per cent of all employees. Most companies have a lower rate of 7 per cent. This report wants to find out why many employees are not happy at work. We will also suggest ways to make work better for employees and keep them.

original: So much of what the speaker said rang true. I honestly believe there's a danger that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't think this is such an issue for my generation who've lived without technology for so long. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know that it's OK to be alone. But the under 20s are another kettle of fish. They're so busy communicating that they never experience the feeling of solitude and run the risk of not learning how to enjoy their own company. In addition, they're learning conversation through messages that can be edited and changed at the expense of learning the art of real conversation in real time with the person in front of you.
simplified:
The speaker says some things are true. I agree that being connected to technology can make us feel lonely. My generation didn't have technology for a long time, so we know how to be alone and that it's okay.

But the young people under 20 are different. They spend a lot of time communicating on their phones and computers. They don't know what it's like to be alone. They might not learn how to enjoy their own company.

Also, they learn to talk to people through messages on their phones. They can change their messages easily. But they don't practice real conversations with people in front of them. This is an important skill to learn.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified:
Don't always say something is wrong. When we say something is wrong and then something is right, people start to ignore the good things. We should say something is good just because it is good.

For example, a student does a good job on a test. We should just say, "Well done!" and not add "But you could have done it faster." Or a friend helps us with something. We should say, "Thank you!" and not say "You could have done it better next time."

This way, people will appreciate the good things and feel happy when we give them positive feedback.

original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Your dreams can show you things you didn't know you were thinking about. Many people have the same common dreams, like flying or falling, losing their teeth, or being naked in public. These dreams probably mean the same thing for everyone. But to understand what they mean to you, you need to connect them to things that happen in your daily life and how you feel.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. simplified: Wild dogs living in Moscow are a fascinating sight. There are about 35,000 wild dogs in the city. Some of these dogs were born wild, while others were once pets that their owners abandoned. These dogs live on their own or in groups. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that they have adapted well to city life. They've learned to cross the road with people for safety, and some dogs even seem to understand traffic lights.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. simplified: People see many things to buy on their phones, in magazines and in shop windows every day. As a result, British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. simplified: Sam looked at the dust on the road from Mr Carter's car as it drove up to the Big House. The horses were annoyed with flies and didn't care that their owner was coming. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't often come out here. This was just fine by Sam because the more he kept out of his boss's way, the longer he'd have a job. Mr Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. simplified: Many people in Berlin, Germany are unhappy about shooting pigs. They think it's cruel and it causes a lot of arguments between hunters and people who love animals. In response to these complaints, the city council decided to do something different. Instead of shooting the pigs, they have put up fences to keep them out of the city. original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story the city of Athens is ruled by Crete, but the Athenians rebel. As a punishment, Minos the king of Crete forces the Athenians to send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The youths are thrown into the labyrinth and eaten by a monster that lives there called the Minotaur. But one of the youths, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.
